Next we’re going to need some awesome fonts. We will get some new fonts from dafont.com. They have a wide selection of cool fonts that can easily grab people attentions. If you are using Photoshop, I suggest you download a style package, their are tons of results on Google. CSS
If you didn’t make a CSS file with the last one, you will be making one now (if you didn’t make one before follow the CSS step in Chapter 1). So first of all, lets put in our background. Now, there are many things that we can do with this, we can make it so it doesn’t repeat and so it does repeat. For this I’m going to make it repeat down the Y axis of my page (I will be using the first background posted above). Repeat code: background-repeat:repeat;. No repeat code: background-repeat:no-repeat;. If your doing something like mine, you should do it like this: background-repeat:repeat y;. That will make the image repeat only going down. If you are doing that, your probably going to want it centered. So we should add this: background-position:top-center;. Are CSS should now look something like this:

Sometimes the image takes a little longer to load, and its the fire image like I’m using, its going to look a bit we’re looking white (default HTML background color).

Now that we have our background, sometimes we don’t want the text getting in the way of out pictures on the site (such as the flames). So we’re going to give a certain area that the text will fit in. This goes by the width of the page. So I’m going to make it so all my text has to fit into 550 pixel width. To make it fit into a certain width, we’re going to make a new divide ID called width: div#width {width: 550px; margin: 10px auto 10px auto; position: relative;}, (we will put this into action in the HTML in the next part).
